title: 105_hr4378
content:
The "Empowering Parents to Fight Drugs Act of 1998" authorizes grants for State educational agencies to implement random drug testing programs for students in grades 7 through 12. State agencies must allocate at least 99.75% of the grant amount to local educational agencies. States must submit applications to the Secretary to receive grants. The "Empowering Parents to Fight Drugs Act of 1998" authorizes grants for State educational agencies to implement random drug testing programs for students in grades 7 through 12. State agencies must allocate funds based on student enrollment ratios to State and local educational agencies. The Act authorizes grants for State educational agencies to implement drug testing programs for students in grades 7 through 12. Administrative costs are limited to $200,000 or 0.10% for the Secretary, 0.25% for State agencies, and 5% for local agencies. The Act authorizes grants for State educational agencies to implement drug testing programs for students in grades 7 through 12. Administrative costs are limited to specific percentages for the Secretary, State agencies, and local agencies. Each local educational agency receiving a grant under this Act must certify to the State educational agency that funds will be used as specified, develop a drug testing program plan for students in grades 7 through 12, and make the plan available to the public for review. The agency is required to conduct drug tests for students in grades 7 through 12 at least once. The local educational agency must conduct drug tests for students in grades 7 through 12 at least once a year, including screening for marijuana, amphetamines, PCP, opiates, and cocaine. After meeting this requirement, remaining funds can be used for law enforcement assistance, such as using drug sniffing dogs, and for additional drug tests on students during the school year. SEC. 5. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. Each local educational agency receiving funds under this Act must inform parents about the random drug testing program, allow parents to opt out at the start of each school year, and provide timely positive test results. They must also maintain confidentiality of student test results and have a medical review officer in place. The medical review officer is responsible for receiving all test results. For the first positive result, they must inform parents and provide information on available resources. For consecutive positive results, parents and school officials will determine the appropriate action based on school policy. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

(1) "medical review officer" is a licensed physician responsible for interpreting student drug test results.
(2) "parent" includes legal guardians or those standing in loco parentis.
(3) "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
(4) "State" encompasses all 50 states and U.S. territories. SEC. 7. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1999 through 2003. SEC. 8. Amendment to ESEA requiring local educational agencies to implement drug testing programs meeting specific criteria by a set deadline.
